title: Protocol for identification and validation of IGF2BP1 target genes in pluripotent human embryonic carcinoma cells
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
UV-crosslinking of the cells and preparation of lysates
Timing: 1 day
This step is to prepare the cellular lysates containing protein-RNA complexes after stabilization by UV-crosslinking.
UV-crosslinking of RNA and associated proteins in live cells.
Remove the medium from the culture dish and wash the cells twice with 8 mL of ice-cold PBS.
Add 6 mL of ice-cold PBS supplemented with 1× complete protease inhibitor and 2 mM dithiothreitol (DTT) to each 10-cm culture dish.
UV-crosslink 5 dishes at a time.
Remove the lid, place the dishes on ice in a tray.
Irradiate the cells with 375 mJ/cm2 at 254 nm using a UV Stratalinker 2400 (Stratagene).
Note: Make sure the PBS covers the cell surface evenly while the plates are on ice.
Cell lysate preparation.
Keep the dishes on ice and harvest the UV-crosslinked cells using a cell scraper. Collect the cells in a 15 mL tube.
Centrifuge the tubes at 3,000 RPM (1741 × g) for 5 min at 4°C. Discard the supernatant.
Wash the cell pellet with ice-cold PBS supplemented with 1× complete Protease inhibitor and 2 mM DTT. Centrifuge the tubes at 3,000 RPM (1741 × g) for 5 min at 4°C. Discard the supernatant.
Prepare lysis buffer by supplementing polysome lysis buffer (PLB) with 2 mM DTT, 1× complete protease inhibitor, 200 units/mL RNaseOUT out and 200 units/mL SUPERase IN.
Add 5-pellet volumes of freshly prepared lysis buffer to the pellets (for instance, 500 μL of lysis buffer to cell pellet volume of 100 μL) and gently resuspend the pellets by pipetting up and down for a few times.
Leave the tubes on ice for 10 min, then place them at −80°C overnight to complete the lysis. Samples can be stored at −80°C until use.
RNA immunoprecipitation (RIP)

Timing: 4 days
Protein-RNA complexes are precipitated using the specific antibody against the protein-of-interest, and RNA is extracted from the precipitated protein-RNA complexes with trizol-chloroform extraction method. RNA extraction is best done using the Trizol-chloroform extraction method, rather than column extraction method. The amount of RNA obtained from immunoprecipitation may be too low for efficient recovery from extraction columns since a certain amount of RNA can be lost in the columns. Extracted RNA is then purified using Phenol:Chloroform:Isoamyl Alcohol.
Bead preparation.
Aliquot 50 μL of beads for each RIP [anti-FLAG M2 beads for RIP of FLAG-tagged IGF2BP1 or Protein A/G Dynabeads® for RIP of endogenous IGF2BP1] to protein low binding tubes (Eppendorf, Cat#0030108132).
Place the tubes on a magnetic stand for 30 s. Remove the solution.
Wash beads 3 times with ice-cold PBS.
Add 500 μL of ice-cold PBS to each tube.
Remove the tubes from the magnetic stand.
Resuspend the beads in ice-cold PBS by gently inverting the tubes. Centrifuge the tubes briefly with Bench top centrifuge to collect residual beads from the cap.
Replace the tubes on the magnetic stand for 30 s until the solution becomes clear.
Remove the supernatant.
Repeat steps (3ci – v) 2 times.
Note: For RIP of FLAG-IGF2BP1 using anti-FLAG affinity beads, proceed to step 4. For RIP of endogenous IGF2BP1, continue with the following steps to conjugate the beads to anti-IGF2BP1 antibody.
Incubate the beads with 250 μL of 5% (w/v) BSA in PBS on a rotator at 4°C for at least 2 h. This blocking step will reduce non-specific interactions.
Lysate preparation and protein concentration measurement can be done while blocking the beads.

After blocking, place the tubes on the magnetic stand until the solution becomes clear, remove the blocking solution and wash the beads with 500 μL of PLB for 2 times.
Add 375 μL of PLB supplemented with protease inhibitor to the washed beads.
Add 5 μg of antibody (anti-IGF2BP1 or rabbit IgG) to the beads to maintain an antibody concentration of 1 μg/75 μL PLB.
Incubate the antibody and beads on a rotator at 4°C for 2 h.
Wash the bead-antibody complex with 1 mL of NT2 buffer 5 times in the same manner as described in step 3c.
Critical: Always keep buffers, reagents, and samples on ice. Clean the tools, surfaces, and gloves with 70% ethanol and RNAse Away Reagent for decontamination.
Lysate preparation.
Thaw the cell lysates (from step 2f) on ice. Once thawed, leave on ice for 5 min.
Spin at 16,000 × g for 15 min at 4°C and collect the supernatant.
Measure the concentration of the lysate by using Pierce Bradford assay according to the manufacturer’s instructions [Pierce™ Coomassie (Bradford) Protein Assay Kit (thermofisher.com[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/order/catalog/product/23200])].
Use 400 μg of cell lysate for each RIP. Keep 10% of lysate as an input control at −80°C.
Immunoprecipitation of RNA-protein complex.
Add 400 μg of cell lysate to the previously washed anti-FLAG M2 affinity beads or bead-antibody complex in Low binding tubes and incubate the reaction mixture on a rotator at 4°C overnight.
18 h later, centrifuge the tubes at 5,000 × g for 30 s at 4°C. Discard supernatant or keep for further analysis.
Wash the beads with 1 mL of ice-cold NT2 buffer supplemented with 1× complete protease inhibitor, 200 units/mL RNaseOUT and 200 units/mL SUPERase IN for 5 times in the same manner as mentioned above in step 3c.

After the last wash, freeze 5% of the beads at −20°C for SDS-PAGE analysis. Beads can be kept at −20°C for 2 months.
Extraction and purification of RNA from immunoprecipitated RNA-protein complex.
Resuspend the remaining beads in 200 μL of 1% SDS-TE buffer supplemented with 20 μg of Proteinase K.
Elute RNA from RIP samples by incubating the samples at 55°C for 30 min on heat block. During this time, the tubes are mixed every 5 min via inversion and brief centrifugation with Bench-top centrifuge.
While eluting RNA from RIP samples, thaw the input lysates on ice.
After centrifugation of RIP samples, place the tubes on the magnetic stand for 30 s and collect the eluent in fresh tubes.
RNA was extracted with trizol-chloroform extraction method using Trizol reagent (Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer’s instructions.
Add 1:1 volume of Trizol reagent to the eluted RNA samples and the input lysates and incubate at room temperature for 5 min.
Add chloroform (use 200 μL per 1 mL of Trizol), shake the tubes vigorously for 15 s and before incubating them at room temperature for 3 min.
Centrifuge the tubes at 12,000 × g for 15 min at 4°C.
Carefully pipette the top layer of aqueous phase that contains RNA (which is around 60% of the total volume of solution) to new 2 mL tubes.
RNA precipitation using ethanol.
Freshly prepare pre-mixed salt solution (40 μL of 5 M NaCl, 26.7 μL of 7.5 M LiCl and 4 μL of 15 mg/mL GlycoBlue for each RIP) and keep it at room temperature.
Add pre-mixed salt solution, followed by 1.5 mL of ice-cold 100% ethanol to the RNA (previously collected in 2 mL tube in step 6e).
Vortex for a few seconds and store at −80°C overnight for 18 h.

Next day, centrifuge the tube at 18,000 × g for 30 min at 4°C.
Wash the RNA pellet with ethanol by adding 1 mL of 75% ethanol, spinning it down at 18,000 × g for 10 min at 4°C and discarding the supernatant. Repeat for one more time.
Air-dry the RNA pellet at room temperature for 30 min.
Resuspend the pellet in 100 μL of DEPC water.
RNA clean-up using Phenol:Chloroform:Isoamyl Alcohol.
Add 100 μL of Phenol:Chloroform:Isoamyl Alcohol (25:24:1, v/v) to 100 μL of the RNA obtained.
Vortex for 1 min and centrifuge the tube at 18,000 × g at room temperature for 5 min.
Transfer the top layer of aqueous phase to a new Eppendorf tube and add equal volume of Chloroform:Isoamyl alcohol (24:1). Vortex for 1 min and centrifuge at 18,000 × g at room temperature for 5 min.
Transfer the upper aqueous layer to a new 2 mL Eppendorf tube.
Add 0.1 volume of 3 M Sodium Acetate (pH 5.2), 3.5 μL of 15 mg/mL GlycoBlue and 2.5 volume of 100% ethanol to the tube, mix and store at −80°C overnight.
Recover the RNA by centrifuging the tube at 18,000 × g for 30 min at 4°C.
Wash the RNA pellet 2 times by adding 1 mL of 75% ethanol, spinning it down at 18,000 × g for 10 min at 4°C and discarding the supernatant.
Air-dry the RNA pellet at room temperature for 30 min.
Resuspend the pellet in DEPC water. Use 10 μL for RIP and 30 μL for input samples. The expected concentration range of RNA input samples would be ∼800–1000 ng per μL.
The RNA obtained can either be sent for sequencing or used for qPCR assay.
cDNA synthesis and qPCR assay
Timing: 1 day

This step is to quantify the RNA bound to RNA-binding proteins by quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) assay. The RNA samples obtained by RIP are used to generate cDNA for qPCR.
cDNA generation from RNA using iScript cDNA synthesis kit (BioRad) according to the manufacturer’s instructions.
Use 2 μL of RNA obtained from each RIP and input sample as templates.
Prepare the master mix of the reagents for all reactions. The amounts of reagents required for each reaction are as below. Total volume of the reaction mix is 20 μL.

Use the cDNA for qPCR assay straight away or keep the samples at −20°C for later use.
Real-time qPCR (quantitative PCR) assay. Transcript enrichment of known target genes and genes of interest is measured by real-time. PCR using iTaq Universal SYBR Green Supermix and QuantStudio3 Real-Time PCR systems.
Make a 1:10 dilution of the cDNA with nuclease-free water and use 4 μL for each qPCR reaction.
Prepare master mix for the qPCR reactions. Perform triplicates for each reaction (i.e., 3 reaction wells for input, 3 for RIP and 3 for control RIP). The reagents required for each qPCR reaction are as follows:

Vortex and spin down the master mix. Add the reaction mix (16 μL) to each well of MicroAmp™ Optical 96-Well Reaction Plate and then add 4 μL of cDNA template to the corresponding wells.
Seal the plate with MicroAmp™ Clear Adhesive Film, vortex for a few seconds to mix the reagents. Centrifuge the plate at 3,000 RPM (1,741 × g) for 1 min to spin down the reagents and remove air bubbles.
Perform the real-time qPCR reaction with the set-up as below.

Transcript enrichment of a target gene in IP sample is presented as percentage of transcript enrichment of the corresponding gene in input samples and calculated as below.
Calculate the average Ct value of the Ct values obtained from triplicates of qPCR reactions of input sample.
Average Ct value of input samples needs to be adjusted since the input samples contain 10% of the IP samples. Calculate the adjusted Ct value by subtracting the value of log210 from the average Ct value of input.
Calculate the delta Ct value of each IP sample by subtracting the adjusted Ct value of input from the Ct value of IP sample.
Calculate the transcript enrichment of a target gene in IP sample as percentage of input by using the formula of 100 × 2ˆ(delta Ct value).
Use HIST2H3A as a negative control gene.
Use SRF and MYC as positive control genes, which are known target genes of IGF2BP1.
m6A immunoprecipitation (m6A-IP)
Timing: 6 days
To ascertain if the transcript detected by the RIP qPCR bears m6A modification, RNA immunoprecipitation using m6A antibody is performed. m6A-IP is done using a previously reported method with some changes.3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3] Please refer to Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1] for the overview of m6A-IP.

Figure 1. Overview of the immunoprecipitation of m6A-enriched RNAs from NTERA-2 cells
RNA preparation.
Seed NTERA-2 cells at 2.5 × 106 cells per 10-cm culture dish in a 10 mL of DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS. Harvest NTERA-2 cells by trypsinization when the cells reach about 90% confluency.
Add 2.5 mL of 0.25% Trypsin-EDTA (Nacalai Tesque) per 10-cm culture dish.
Incubate at 37°C in a CO2 incubator for 5–10 min.
Collect the detached cells in a 15-mL tube and spin down at 2,000 RPM (774 × g) for 5 min.

Remove the medium and wash the cell pellet with ice-cold PBS by resuspension in 1 mL of ice-cold PBS. Transfer the cell suspension to a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube for centrifugation at 2,000 RPM (774 × g) for 5 min at 4°C.
Discard the supernatant and use the cell pellet for RNA extraction or store the pellet at −80°C.
Extract total RNA from the cell pellets with the Trizol reagent (Invitrogen) as described in step 6e. Collect the aqueous layer containing RNA in a new 2 mL Eppendorf tube.
Precipitate the RNA by adding 0.1 volume of 3 M Sodium Acetate (pH 5.2), GlycoBlue (100 μg per mL as a final concentration) and 2.5 volumes of 100% ethanol to the sample. Mix and keep at −80°C overnight.
Recover the RNA by centrifuging the tube at 18,000 × g for 30 min at 4°C.
Wash the RNA pellet with 1 mL of 75% ethanol. Centrifuge at 18,000 × g for 10 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Air-dry the RNA pellet at room temperature for 30 min.
Resuspend the pellet in 150 μL of DEPC water.
Perform DNase I (QIAGEN) treatment of RNA to eliminate genomic DNA contamination.
Add a mixture of DNase I (5 μL) and RDD buffer (20 μL) to the RNA.
Incubate at room temperature for 15 min.
Do the RNA clean up as described in step 6f. Resuspend the pellet in 85 μL of DEPC water.
Measure the RNA concentration using the Nanodrop Spectrophotometer. The expected concentration of RNA input samples would range between 1000–1200 ng per μL.
Use 150 ng of total RNA as an input, and 3 μg of RNA for IP.
Bead preparation.
Prepare 50 μL of Protein A/G Dynabeads® per IP. Transfer the beads to Low binding tubes.

Place the tubes on a magnetic stand for 30 s. Remove the supernatant from the beads.
Wash the beads 3 times with 500 μL of ice-cold PBS per wash, as described previously in RIP (step 3c).
Add 250 μL of 0.5% BSA in PBS to the washed beads.
Add 10 μg of m6A antibody or rabbit IgG antibody to the beads.
Place the tubes on a rotator and incubate at 4°C for 2 h.
Wash the bead-antibody complex 3 times with 1 mL of IP buffer (50 mM Tris-HCL (pH 7.4), 750 mM NaCl and 0.5% NP-40), as described in step 3c.
Immunoprecipitation of m6A-modified RNAs.
Add 3 μg of RNA from step 10k to the bead-antibody complex in IP buffer (50 mM Tris-HCL (pH 7.4), 750 mM NaCl and 0.5% NP-40) supplemented with 200 units/mL RNaseOUT and 200 units/mL SUPERase IN. Incubate on a rotator at 4°C overnight.
After overnight incubation, the tubes containing the RNA-antibody complexes were placed on the magnetic stand and washed 3 times with IP buffer in the same manner as mentioned in the step 3c.
Isolate and purify RNA bound to m6A antibody as described in step 6.
Perform cDNA synthesis from the precipitated RNA, followed by qPCR assay (mentioned in the steps 8 and 9) to ascertain if the RNAs, such as those previously identified by IGF2BP1 RIP, contain m6A modification.
Functional validation of RNA targets and m6A-modified RNA targets
Timing: 7 days
To validate the RNA targets detected by RIP and m6A-IP, the mRNA and/or protein expression levels of the targets are examined in in NTERA-2 cells following siRNA-based knockdown of RNA-binding protein (IGF2BP1) or methyltransferase enzymes (METTL3 and METT14).
Transfect NTERA-2 cells with siRNAs targeting IGF2BP1, METTL3 or METTL14.

Seed 0.5 × 106 of NTERA-2 cells in 6-well culture plates. Prepare triplicates for each siRNA target.
24 h after seeding, transfect the cells with siRNAs targeting IGF2BP1, METTL3, METTL14, or non-targeting control siRNA using jetPRIME (Polypus Transfection Reagent) according to the manufacturer’s instructions.
Prepare the master mix for triplicates of each siRNA target. The amounts of reagents used for each reaction are 35 nM siRNA, 200 μL of jetPrime buffer and 4 μL of jetPrime reagent.
Add siRNA and jetPrime buffer to an Eppendorf tube, vortex for 10 s and spin down.
Add jetPrime reagent to the mixture, vortex for 1 s and spin down.
Incubate the reaction mixture for 10 min at room temperature.
Add the reaction mixture to the cell culture plate in a dropwise manner and rock the plate gently.
Incubate the cells at 37°C in a CO2 incubator for 48 h.
Note: Keep siRNAs at −20°C. Make aliquots (∼25 μL) of siRNAs at the concentration of 20 μM to minimize the freeze-thaw cycles. The siRNA should not frozen and thawed more than twice.
48 h after transfection, trypsinize the cells from each reaction well and seed one-fourth of the cells into a well of a 6-well plate (for RNA extraction) and three-fourth of the cells to a 6 cm dish (for protein extraction).
6–8 h after seeding, perform a second transfection with the corresponding siRNA complexes as described above in step 15b.
72 h after the second transfection, harvest the cells by trypsinisation and store the cell pellets at −80°C.
Total RNA extraction and real-time qPCR assays for quantification of target gene expression.

Extract total RNA from the frozen cell pellets in step 15e using RNeasy Mini Kit (Qiagen) with the removal of genomic DNA using the RNase-free DNase Set (Qiagen), according to the manufacturer’s instructions.
Perform cDNA synthesis from 1 μg RNA using iScript reverse transcription supermix for RT-qPCR (Bio-Rad).
Perform qPCR assay using iTaq Universal SYBR green kit (Bio-Rad) and QuantStudio3 Real-Time PCR systems (Thermo Fisher Scientific).
Note: Details are as mentioned in steps 8 and 9.
Calculate the fold-change in the expression levels of target genes in the cells treated with siRNA targeting IGF2BP1 or methyl transferases compared to control cells using the 2−ΔCT method.
Note: Housekeeping gene GAPDH is used as a normalization control.
Quantification of protein expression levels of target genes using immunoblot analysis.
Prepare RIPA lysis buffer supplemented with 1 × Halt phosphatase inhibitor, 1 × Complete protease inhibitor and 1 mM PMSF.
To extract protein from the cell pellets, resuspend the frozen pellets in RIPA buffer with gentle pipetting. The lysates are then incubated on ice for 45 min. Centrifuge lysates at 13,500 RPM (18,340 × g) for 15 min at 4°C.
Collect the supernatant (cell lysate) in a new tube. Measure the protein concentrations of lysates using the Pierce BCA Protein Assay kit.
Load 40 μg of protein into each well of 8% SDS/PAGE gel. Run the gel using PowerPac Basic Power Supply system (Bio-Rad, Cat#1645050) at 125 V for 2 h.
Transfer the proteins from the gel to PVDF membrane using Mini Trans-Blot cell system (Bio-Rad, Cat# 1703930) at 30 V and 100 mA, overnight in the cold room.
Detect the expression levels of proteins of interest.
Block the membrane using 10% milk in PBS-T (PBS with 0.1% tween-20) for 30 min at room temperature.

Incubate the membrane with primary antibody diluted in the blocking buffer at the ratio of 1:1000 at 4°C overnight.
Wash the membrane 3 times with PBS-T at 10 min per wash.
Incubate the membrane with secondary antibody (HRP-conjugated anti-rabbit or anti-mouse) diluted in the blocking buffer at the ratio of 1:10,000 at room temperature for 1 h.
Wash the membrane 3 times with PBS-T at 10 min per wash.
Perform Enhanced Chemiluminescence (ECL) detection using Radiance or Radiance Plus ECL reagent (Azure Biosystems, Cat # AC2101 or AC2103).
Note: 8% SDS/PAGE gel is used since the molecular weights of the proteins of interest range between 50–200 kDA. Commercially available precast 4%–20% gradient gels can be used for separation of proteins with a wider range of molecular weights.
